Award.AwardTitle: Scale-Up of Selective STEM Specialty Schools: Effi

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The desire to better empower high-ability STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) students has contributed in the last two decades to a jump in the creation of selective STEM specialty high schools. These schools devote all of their attention to a student body comprised only of the most talented students, ones who are most likely to be able to learn the most demanding STEM content, reach their STEM learning potential, and pursue postsecondary STEM study and careers. However, there are mixed views on the role that selective STEM specialty schools play in achieving their mission. While commenting on what is known regarding education in the STEM disciplines, a recent National Research Council report entitled "Successful K-12 STEM Education" notes that "there are no systematic data that show whether the highly capable students who attend those schools would have been just as likely to pursue a STEM major or related career or make significant contributions to technology or science if they had attended another type of school." To address the research gap, this impact study addresses the question: Does gaining admission to a selective STEM specialty school improve students' academic success on the SAT, SAT II (Math Level 2), and Advanced Placement exams (Calculus AB, Chemistry, and Physics B)? Other portions of the investigation follow additional student outcomes, including: participation and success in STEM competitions; STEM publications; National Merit scholarships; intentions for postsecondary STEM education and STEM careers; and initial postsecondary STEM education.

This study is based on the most rigorous possible design for the focal topic: a true experimental investigation of outcomes for students from many selective STEM specialty schools. The study is being accomplished through random assignment of equivalent treatment and control groups, and based on enough students to yield statistical power that can produce the most clear causal result possible. Researchers are recruiting all qualified students who apply for admission to 20 selective STEM specialty schools among the approximately 100 such schools currently in the United States. For the class entering in fall 2013, study schools are revising their routine selection process to one of assigning students for acceptance (treatment condition) or not (control condition) through random assignment of qualified applicants. Researchers, then, are following treatment students via their STEM schools and also intensively tracking all control students wherever they continue their secondary education. The study also investigates relative cost-effectiveness for educating high-achieving students in selective STEM schools versus educating them at other schools.

Since there is an acute and growing U.S. shortage of STEM professionals and technicians, it is imperative for the nation's education system to ensure that talented STEM students are reaching their maximum potential and pursuing postsecondary STEM degree programs and careers. As one strategy increasingly being used to address this need is to educate talented STEM students in selective STEM specialty schools, this study is informing considerations of the cost/benefit of directing resources to support such schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study helps strengthen a thin amount of previous research on a small but important part of the nation?s STEM education system for getting more high school students to pursue college STEM education and STEM careers, selective STEM specialty schools. The benefits of these selective schools primarily have been documented through the schools' own self-studies, which show that their talented students go on to postsecondary STEM majors and STEM careers. This study is a rare independent investigation.

Inclusive STEM specialty schools (open to all students, e.g., magnet schools), which are many and growing in number all the time, have been studied to some extent. In contrast, selective STEM specialty schools (requiring rigorous applications and selecting only highly talented students) have been understudied, perhaps in part because there only are a few hundred of them. However, given the more intensive resources needed to create and operate these selective schools, there is a policy importance to having independent research about them. 

The research design of the strongest previous external studies has compared students in these selective STEM schools to similarly talented students in other schools; however, there could be a motivational difference between these two student groups since most students in other schools never applied to selective STEM schools. To address this research design limitation, all participants in this study are students who applied to selective STEM schools and, therefore, shared such a motivation. The study compares those students who were accepted and attended selective schools to those accepted and declining to attend, those on waiting lists, and students who attended selective schools but discontinued.

Two lines of investigation were (a) factors influencing students' "STEM pathways" from entering high school through one year of college, and (b) factors influencing formation of students' "STEM identities" from their initial recruitment to apply to selective STEM specialty schools to completion of high school. Over the entire grant period, survey data were collected annually from 269 students, from entering high school through one year of college. All students applied to one of nine selective STEM specialty schools: 206 attended the schools and 63 were qualified and not accepted, declined an offer to attend, or discontinued attending. Additionally, retrospective interviews were conducted with a sample of 32 study participants when they had completed one year of college; seventeen staff members at STEM specialty schools were also interviewed.

STEM Pathways. Students who attended selective STEM schools showed higher aspirations to pursue STEM after high school than those who attended other high schools. Results were mixed with respect to attainment in high school. Students who had increased access/reduced barriers to information and opportunities about STEM educational offerings before entering high school, and received key supports during high school, exhibited higher attainment during and after high school. Level of parent education also represented a significant predictor of continued participation in STEM after high school. Students in STEM schools faced increased burdens such as daily travel to school, but also had access to more extracurricular clubs; however, students in STEM schools reported lower participation rates in those STEM clubs than that of students at other schools.

STEM Identity Formation. Two main themes emerged in differences between STEM-attending and comprehensive-attending students, plus students who left the selective schools. First, STEM-attending students had more detailed, specific, and focused conceptions of their STEM identity. Second, both STEM-attending students and ones who left saw their STEM identity in conflict with other academic identities. Students felt that having interests outside of STEM, such as liberal arts, music, culinary arts, or being ?creative,? made them less of a STEM person.

Some of this independent study's core results are similar to the schools' own research on a foundational goal for selective STEM schools. That is, for students in selective STEM schools, interest in STEM postsecondary study and careers does grow during the high school years and persists into college. Further, students in selective STEM schools have a more detailed understanding of careers in STEM than comparable students in other schools.

Selective STEM specialty schools might examine other results in this study to consider changes toward reducing the number of students who discontinue, by improving the life balance of all attending students and supporting any students interested in more integration of STEM with other fields. Student perception that having academic or extracurricular interests outside of STEM conflicts with having a STEM identity led to discomfort and contributed to students? decision to leave the school or created stress if students remained. The frontiers of science are increasingly focused not only on interdisciplinary work among STEM fields but also on the interface of STEM and other fields. Encouraging rather than even inadvertently discouraging students who identify themselves as having such interest would be helpful for the nation's STEM enterprise.
